story:
Our Story

Global Mental Health Initiatives is a u.s based 501 (c) 3 organization dedicate to treating mental illness in resource-poor communities. In 2009 gmhi founder John McInerney was visiting the village of Kalenga, Tanzania when he encountered the funeral of a young woman who had committed suicide the previous day. He subsequently heard reports of a 'tradition' of suicide in the area.


Today our research shows that Kalenga, Tanzania has the highest suicide rate in the world


Suicide is not just a symptom of mental illness. It is an indicator of extreme community distress. Villages like Kalenga have suffered generations of extreme poverty and have been ravaged by illness and diseases such as HIV/AIDS. Primary health care facilities are both inadequate and overwhelmed and mental health care is virtually non-existent. There is an urgent need to address the social, psychological and epidemiological roots of suicide in Kalenga and neighboring villages but there are no local or national resources to achieve this.

Causes of suicide in Kalenga

Village elders in Kalenga report the causes of suicide as

  • Extra marital pregnancy
  • Promiscuity and marital discord
  • Social humiliation
  • Alcohol abuse

Women in Kalenga commit suicide one and a half times more than men.


Women and girls tend to carry an unfair share of the burden of poverty. Children, the most vulnerable members of society, suffer most.

How gmhi will help


The government of Tanzania has approved  our work in Kalenga and supports our continuing initiatives to:
  • Expand our work into the nearby villages
  • Establish a suicide prevention program
  • Complete a resource inventory of the villages
  • Establish contact with other NGO's in the region to develop working partnerships

Our committment.

gmhi uses Participatory Action and Capacity Building approaches. We engage local people, provide training and support and work with them to discover solutions to local problems. This gives people a stake in the outcome and builds community cohesion, which in turn acts as a barrier against deterioration of community strengths. We use cost-effective on-line and local resources to monitor progress and achieve project sustainability. 

How you can help

  • We urgently need to raise $5000 to launch the next phase of our work in Kalenga. Your donation will help us to achieve our goals.
  • Please send your check or money order made payable to gmhi Inc. to: gmhi, 24 East 12th St.,  Suite 503, New York, NY 10003
  • To donate auctionable items or services please call John McInerney at 212 645 8059 or email him at john@gmhi.org

We received generous donations of Bruce Springsteen and Steve Buscemi celebrity memorabilia for our up-coming on-line auction! More items to come! Go to http://www.gmhi.org for more information.
story_txt:
Our Story
Global Mental Health Initiatives is a u.s based 501 (c) 3 organization dedicate to treating mental illness in resource-poor communities. In 2009 gmhi founder John McInerney was visiting the village of Kalenga, Tanzania when he encountered the funeral of a young woman who had committed suicide the previous day. He subsequently heard reports of a 'tradition' of suicide in the area.


Today our research shows that Kalenga, Tanzania has the highest suicide rate in the world


Suicide is not just a symptom of mental illness. It is an indicator of extreme community distress. Villages like Kalenga have suffered generations of extreme poverty and have been ravaged by illness and diseases such as HIV/AIDS. Primary health care facilities are both inadequate and overwhelmed and mental health care is virtually non-existent. There is an urgent need to address the social, psychological and epidemiological roots of suicide in Kalenga and neighboring villages but there are no local or national resources to achieve this.

Causes of suicide in Kalenga
Village elders in Kalenga report the causes of suicide as

Extra marital pregnancy
Promiscuity and marital discord 
Social humiliation
Alcohol abuse

Women in Kalenga commit suicide one and a half times more than men.
Women and girls tend to carry an unfair share of the burden of poverty. Children, the most vulnerable members of society, suffer most.How gmhi will help 
The government of Tanzania has approved  our work in Kalenga and supports our continuing initiatives to:
Expand our work into the nearby villages
Establish a suicide prevention program 
Complete a resource inventory of the villages
Establish contact with other NGO's in the region to develop working partnerships 


Our committment.
gmhi uses Participatory Action and Capacity Building approaches. We engage local people, provide training and support and work with them to discover solutions to local problems. This gives people a stake in the outcome and builds community cohesion, which in turn acts as a barrier against deterioration of community strengths. We use cost-effective on-line and local resources to monitor progress and achieve project sustainability. 
How you can help

We urgently need to raise $5000 to launch the next phase of our work in Kalenga. Your donation will help us to achieve our goals. 

Please send your check or money order made payable to gmhi Inc. to: gmhi, 24 East 12th St.,  Suite 503, New York, NY 10003
To donate auctionable items or services please call John McInerney at 212 645 8059 or email him at john@gmhi.org

We received generous donations of Bruce Springsteen and Steve Buscemi celebrity memorabilia for our up-coming on-line auction! More items to come! Go to http://www.gmhi.org for more information.

story:
Our Plea

Dear Community,
Our dear friend and beloved author, Tara Hardy, needs help. In January 2012, we came to you after Tara had been in the hospital with a life-threatening, undiagnosed health condition. Since that fundraiser, Tara has been admitted to the hospital three more times, has undergone chemotherapy, and is fighting to stay alive.

Our first fundraiser was to help Tara seek a diagnosis. After going to doctor after doctor as her symptoms worsened, she now has a diagnosis. Two of them: a life threatening blood disorder called I.T.P. and an underlying immune disorder called Lyme Disease (more below).

We have put together this donation page to help alleviate some of the financial burden Tara faces. She is currently undergoing a rigorous two-year treatment, the cost of which not covered by health insurance is $18,000 per year. 

Tara’s work as a poet, queer activist, and teacher has strengthened so many hearts across this country and we want more than anything to pay it forward. No contribution is too small. Our overall goal is to fundraise as much as we can to help Tara sustain good medical care.

Tara’s local community in Seattle is also organizing a benefit for Friday, May 31st called BOOST: Poetry to Uplift Your Spirits. Please consider donating a book of your poems or artwork to be sold at the BOOST show.

Email BOOSTSeattle@gmail.com for more information or to get our mailing address.

Signed,
Karen Finneyfrock
Sara Brickman
Elaina Ellis
Greg Brisendine
Ela Barton
Maya Hersh
Casey Tonnelly
Kathleen Nacozy
Debbie Carlsen
Kristina Armenakis
Cedar Adison Smith
Dorothy Kent

 

Gratitude, and A Note About Privilege (from Tara)

It is my tremendous fortune to have such a loving and generous community of people to ask for help. My gratitude overwhelms me, rearranges me. The love and support that have come my way during the last year have shifted my notions about humanity and the universe. Community literally keeps me alive.

Additionally, I want to acknowledge the privilege it is to have a community of people I can ask for help. Speaking of privilege, among other things, being able-bodied for so many years allowed me to cultivate such a community. However, I am no more deserving than the many people who live with challenges such as chronic illness. So many chronically ill people go without support; I believe we should all be more concerned about this (me included). The problem is systemic. Not only is there a crisis regarding access to health care in the U.S., but the isolation surrounding illness and disability is a cultural issue that we must address for every person to be valued, supported, and surrounded by vital community. In the name of supporting community, I encourage us all to give what we can to people who need help. Speaking of…

 

Please Help Support These Remarkable Poets (and More!)

These remarkable poets are also dealing with health issues. Please consider donating to their campaigns to keep poeting.

Fran Varian is one of Tara's mentors and a very dear, very critical human and poet. Click here to donate to her campaign.

Heather Askeland was nominated for a Pushcart last year! Click here to donate to her campaign.

Patch Avery is astonishingly talented, mentors young writers, and is a vital member of the poetry community. Click here to donate to his campaign.

And then, because it feels awesome for community to take care of each other, let’s keep on sharing resources with each other. Yay interdependence! Interdependence rocks!

 

Questions and Answers:

What are Tara’s diagnoses?  I.T.P. (Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura) is a rare blood disorder that causes one’s platelets to disappear without warning, putting one at risk for internal bleeding including brain hemorrhage. Doctors have no idea what causes I.T.P.

Lyme Disease is caused by being bitten by an infected tick, and is called the “great imitator” for the way it mimics many illnesses, making it difficult to diagnose. The disease is chronic, but with treatment many patients regain some level of health. If you want to learn more about the growing epidemic of Lyme Disease, you may watch a documentary called “Under Our Skin” for free on Hulu: http://www.hulu.com/watch/268761.

And/or read a fantastic book that won the American Medical Writer’s Association best book award for 2009, called Cure Unknown: http://www.powells.com/biblio/1-9780312378134-0.

 

What are Tara’s treatments?  Last summer Tara underwent an I.V. chemotherapy designed to kill the cells in her immune system that were destroying her platelets. The drug is estimated to be effective for nine months, at which point we’ll be crossing our fingers that she has entered a long-term remission.

Tara is also receiving treatment for Lyme Disease, which includes an intense regimen of antibiotics and other drugs, the side effects of which are fairly debilitating and much like chemotherapy.

 

How will the money that is raised be used?  The money will be used to cover the portion of Tara’s medical treatment not covered by health insurance.

 

How is Tara doing/feeling?  Tara is in a stage of treatment when the medications actually make her feel worse. She is unable to work. Last fall she taught in a high school one day a week, but those days would send her to bed for several days each time. Here and there she is able to teach a two-hour class (while seated). Whenever she is up to it, she loves to jump on stage and perform a poem or two. 

Tara is writing like mad. She has written an entirely new book of poems about body and illness. She is also writing a book about writing (a writer’s guide to undoing self-sabotage).

In Tara’s words, “Mostly, I’m in a full-time fight for my life. But, strangely, there’s a lot of beauty in here. There’s an unexpected amount of humor, and I regularly experience an unfathomable gratitude for my life. Illness is a remarkable, if brutal, teacher. More than anything, I’m grateful for my community who keeps me alive. The fact that people want me on this planet keeps me rooted here.”

 

What does Tara need?  Mostly, she needs health care right now. To that end, your donation means a lot. But our love and support also help (and some really cute hoop earrings wouldn’t hurt).

 

What is BOOST?  BOOST is a grassroots model that people can use to raise money for health care costs. Tara was inspired to create it after attending one of the regular queer events in Portland that benefits a different community member each time. She has long thought that Seattle needs just such a thing, but BOOST is not just for Seattle, you can use it anywhere! Just email BOOSTSeattle@gmail.com for information. 

BOOST is also a show. The second BOOST show will be Friday, May 31st at 7:30 p.m. at Richard Hugo House, 1634 11th Avenue, Seattle. (See Facebook invite for details.) The BOOST show will benefit Tara Hardy, and will be an evening filled with poetry guaranteed to lift your spirits. That's right, an entire evening of uplifting poems! (What?! Who ever heard of such a thing?!)  

 

What is the best way to contact Tara?  Please leave a comment here on Indiegogo. Even if Tara isn’t able to reply, she’ll be reading messages here. Your support makes a huge difference with her.

story:
Vision Dots can help a billion people see that the world does care about them by allowing them to build themselves a pair of glasses.
 
 
Quick intro      Can something so simple actually work?
 
Vision Dots are at the moment the simplest solution to provide eye care to the poor. Showing off Vision Dots as a viable alternative in eye care is our focus. We have the solution that makes the most sense and our focus is to make enough noise to get Vison Dots implemented fast. Simplicity unfortunately is the only possible solution to this complex problem. It is not in the worlds best interest to have a billion people not contributing fully to their society because they don't have access to glasses that cost a dollar.
 
Our focus is to pilot Vision Dots in a real setting and try to understand if the glasses or the way they are dispensed can be improved. Once everything has been perfected we are going to encourage organizations and governments to implement our vision.
 
We need help to provide the proof that Vision Dots and the idea of self serve eye care will work. Documenting the effort in real time will make the logic and simplicity come to life. Serving 10 000 people at one location with eye care in a day requieres a new way of thinking. Vision Dots hopefully will start an evolution of implementing simplicity to a world that is leaving too many issues and people in the dark. 
 
Just image the word gets out in your overcrowded village " they " are allowing you to build a pair of glasses on Tuesday. 8000 people start to line up and you the organiser better keep the line moving despensing glasses. Doing in depth eye exams for every single person just can't work in a setting like this. Involving the patient is the only solution to serve the masses. "Grab a plate and make yourself a pair of glasses"
 
 
 
The Problem
 
It is estimated that up to one billion people aren’t able to afford corrective eye care. In essence what this really means is we have one billion people struggling with simple daily actives, not being able to earn an income,  not being able to do well in school or whatever else poor vision throws at these individuals.
 
The New York Times  estimates http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/27/health/investing-in-eyeglasses-for-poor-would-boost-international-economy.html?_r=1&  that it would cost 28 billion to provide this group with eye care services and in return these individuals with proper vision could  generate 200 billion dollars worth of additional economical output. 
 
The World Health Organization http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/90/10/12-104034/en/ is suggesting to train a huge network of eye care specialists to deal with the masses that need eye care. The shortage of trained optometrists is staggering and the WHO is suggesting to train 68 000 eye care specialists and create facilities and purchase equipment to solve the current epidemic. The estimate for such a radical approach  would be 28 billion dollars and would take decades to implement. Even with this massive expenditure we still have to remember that not a single person has received a pair of eye glasses.
 
The Stanford Social Innovation review describes all current efforts to provide eye care to the poor in this article. 
http://www.ssireview.org/articles/entry/better_vision_for_the_poor
The article is really describing the attempts made by all groups as having no impact on the current crisis. The issue of all the solutions simply costing too much money for the poor to afford, seems to be the major issue and main reason non of the attempts have worked. The direct delivery also doesn't work since no eye care specialsts are available to assist in prescribing glasses.

Providing vision for the poor needs the simplest solution possible.

My name is Jeff Widderich from Victoria BC. I am an inventor. I make a living using the concepts that I create and make products out of the ideas. I invent, create, build and sell what I have inside my brain. I am very good at taking concepts and turning them into reality efficiently and with a great deal of pride. 

The concept " Vision For The Poor " and the solution to the problem "Vision Dots" is an enormous undertaking to even contemplate solving with out support. I am asking for help. My drive and passion is to see this concept help the estimated 1billion people that can't afford eye care to finally see their world clearly.

All current solutions that attempt to provide eye care are not working because they are too complex or way too expensive. 

 

Vision Dots solves following issues that have been plaguing other attempts

* cost under a dollar to make per pair ( order of 10 000)

* self prescribing (involving eye care professionals simply isn't an option they aren't available in the regions Vision Dots are needy)

How to deliver eye care (simplified approach)

a) form a line grab a plate and build a pair of glasses as you are walking beside a table with all the components and different lenses laid out on tables. Eye Charts are in place for the self examination. (buffet style) 

b) open a tackle box and provide eye care similar to applying a bandage. Everything needed is inside the box. Schools and disaster relief. ( tackle box eye care)

* compact shipping due to the size of the product and how the frames fit inside each other. We estimate 10 000 pairs to fit inside one cubic meter. (36  cubic feet). " Reduces shipping costs immensely and the shipment would be easier to conceal entering dangerous regions where theft is rampant.

Additional benefits

  • New glasses, no sorting of mountains of used glasses with odd prescriptions. Each eye can have a different prescription simply by popping in a specific lens.
  • Shipments are so compact that they can be shipped directly from the factory to the area of the world that needs them. 1 cubic meter = 10 000 pairs
  • The lenses are of extremely good quality (UV and scratch coating) 
  • The lens frame is so flexible you can apply incredible force before they don't break (soft plastic)
  • The string that holds the pair together will make it easy for children to conceal their pride and joy and it will be harder for them to loose the glasses.
  • If for example an order of 10 000 lenses is being produced. We have already established  with the manufacturer the ratios we need to produce for the different prescriptions.
  • Existing efforts to provide eye care to the poor will rapidly switch over to the concept of Vision Dots which would make distribution efforts a lot more effective.(piggy backing)
  • The tackle boxes make a great business opportunity for the poor to make a living selling mobile eye care.  
  • The poor would feel a sense of accomplishment building their own pair of glasses on the spot.
  • glasses allow the poor to work and children will do better in school being able to seethe black board or read books.
  • the Vision Dot design is better suited for the rough and tumble world of living in poverty. They are part of the body once the string tightens the lenses.

Costs to go live 

Rapid prototyping

Finish all prototyping work for Vision Dots and Vision sticks, nose clips  ( the device used to hold lenses up when the patient is checking the different lenses     4800.00

We are still working on making the frames look really fashionable and possibly even more streamlined.

 

Glass set up

Pay the eye glass manufacturers 3200.00 to make casting dyes that fit the frames perfectly. Currently they are cutting these tiny lenses out of bigger stock to make samples.

(Manufacturer in place) 6 month relationship  Prices quoted samples in place

Injection molds

Finalize CAD drawings from the prototyping efforts and start the injection molds for the frames. The molds would be a set of 6 left frames and 6 right frames set up to be stamped once bringing the price down to 10 - 14 cents per frame.   30 000.00- 40 000

Two Vision stick molds  6 000 - 8 000

Nose clips 2400 -3000

(Manufacturer in place ) established relationship for 7 years      Prices quoted 

Tackle Boxes

The model to be used is already tooled and is perfect for 300 sets of glasses with 40 different prescriptions, six Vision sticks, clips and string. 

Order 1000 tackle boxes at a price of 7.87 each       7 870.00- 10 000.00

(Manufacturer in place) new relationship  Prices quoted  samples in place

Build 1000 Tackle Boxes

at a price of 48 000.00 to 60 000.00 

Delivery of those boxes to deserving schools through the Red Cross 3800 - 4800

Eye Charts

Buy 1500 eye charts   1.78 to include in all packages    

 

One Skid pilot project

10 000 bulk packed lenses, 10 000 frames 100 vision sticks, string and nose clips, eye charts, shipping and duties

(Buffet Concept)

Donated to an existing organization with the strict requirement that the distribution process is documented in full. Short falls and successes are documented. I want to be present when the Vision Dots “ hit the street’’ to film the process to see first hand. Also use this video to gain more publicity.

38 000 to 49 000  

 

The Impact 

This direct approach of getting this project done is the only way it is going to happen. The real idea would be to get to the people directly, documenting the effort and spreading the results virally on Youtube and other forms of Social Media. The cost of the injection moulds is a big hindrance.  Once the Vision Dots start popping up the snow ball will start rolling. In action the concept will make sense and more importantly it will attract all kinds of praise from the press. Many organizations have already been approached and really think it is a great solution. Piggy backing on their existing efforts will prove “Vision For The Poor” is actually the concept most likely to succeed since the starting parameters give it a fighting chance.

I think once the poor understand how much a pair of glasses can improve their lives the message will spread and glasses will become more main stream amongst the poor. The entire process of Vision Dots is a huge learning curve for all involved. This project has to  be completed.

If for example an order of 10 000 lenses is being produced. We have already established  with the manufacturer the ratios we need to produce for the different prescriptions.
 Existing efforts to provide eye care to the poor will rapidly switch over to the concept of Vision Dots which would make distribution efforts a lot more effective.(piggy backing)
The tackle boxes make a great business opportunity for the poor to make a living selling mobile eye care.  
The poor would feel a sense of accomplishment building their own pair of glasses on the spot.
glasses allow the poor to work and children will do better in school being able to seethe black board or read books.
the Vision Dot design is better suited for the rough and tumble world of living in poverty. They are part of the body once the string tightens the lenses.

Costs to go live 
Rapid prototyping
Finish all prototyping work for Vision Dots and Vision sticks, nose clips  ( the device used to hold lenses up when the patient is checking the different lenses     4800.00
 We are still working on making the frames look really fashionable and possibly even more streamlined.
 
Glass set up
Pay the eye glass manufacturers 3200.00 to make casting dyes that fit the frames perfectly. Currently they are cutting these tiny lenses out of bigger stock to make samples.
(Manufacturer in place) 6 month relationship  Prices quoted samples in place
Injection molds
Finalize CAD drawings from the prototyping efforts and start the injection molds for the frames. The molds would be a set of 6 left frames and 6 right frames set up to be stamped once bringing the price down to 10 - 14 cents per frame.   30 000.00- 40 000
Two Vision stick molds  6 000 - 8 000
Nose clips 2400 -3000
(Manufacturer in place ) established relationship for 7 years      Prices quoted 
Tackle Boxes
The model to be used is already tooled and is perfect for 300 sets of glasses with 40 different prescriptions, six Vision sticks, clips and string. 
Order 1000 tackle boxes at a price of 7.87 each       7 870.00- 10 000.00
(Manufacturer in place) new relationship  Prices quoted  samples in place
Build 1000 Tackle Boxes
at a price of 48 000.00 to 60 000.00 
Delivery of those boxes to deserving schools through the Red Cross 3800 - 4800
Eye Charts
Buy 1500 eye charts   1.78 to include in all packages    
 
One Skid pilot project
10 000 bulk packed lenses, 10 000 frames 100 vision sticks, string and nose clips, eye charts, shipping and duties
(Buffet Concept)
Donated to an existing organization with the strict requirement that the distribution process is documented in full. Short falls and successes are documented. I want to be present when the Vision Dots “ hit the street’’ to film the process to see first hand. Also use this video to gain more publicity.
38 000 to 49 000  
 
The Impact 
This direct approach of getting this project done is the only way it is going to happen. The real idea would be to get to the people directly, documenting the effort and spreading the results virally on Youtube and other forms of Social Media. The cost of the injection moulds is a big hindrance.  Once the Vision Dots start popping up the snow ball will start rolling. In action the concept will make sense and more importantly it will attract all kinds of praise from the press. Many organizations have already been approached and really think it is a great solution. Piggy backing on their existing efforts will prove “Vision For The Poor” is actually the concept most likely to succeed since the starting parameters give it a fighting chance.
I think once the poor understand how much a pair of glasses can improve their lives the message will spread and glasses will become more main stream amongst the poor. The entire process of Vision Dots is a huge learning curve for all involved. This project has to  be completed.

story:
Help Send Mom With Cancer On Dream Vacation

My mom was diagnoised with Brain Cancer earlier this year. She had a Grade 4 glioblastoma tumor on the upper right side of her head. Surgeons were able to remove 95% of what was abnormal in her brain. Unfortunately this type of cancer, as you can imagine, is quite dangerous and aggresive. We hope that she will be able to survive and beat this, but there is also a chance that her life expecentacy is 2-5 years. 

My mother's dream was always to go to Paris. As an only child, I have had to use a lot of my financial resources to help pay for any medical or personal bills, making money very tight now-a-days. I would really love to give her this gift which is why I am turning to Indiegogo and hoping that the kindness of others will help me raise enough money to take her on her dream vacation.

Any money raised that is not needed for the trip will go towards helping to pay for any medical and personal bills that still need to be paid for. 

For any of you that know my mom personally, please do not tell her about this! I am hoping to surprise her. 

I wish I could offer cool perks, but I promise I am super thankful for anyone that donates and would be glad to send you all a Paris postcard and thank you card :)

 

About my mom, Maria:


My mom was born in Brazil, in a small town outside of Belo Horizonte. She is one of eight, and had to quickly learn to take care of herself and the rest of her large family as she was one of the oldest. My mother was always a hard worker. Around the age of 10, she would pick bananas and coffee beans from the farm she grew up on and would go into town on horse selling whatever she could to make extra money for the family. Before picking up and leaving to move to the U.S., she was a nurse in a hosiptial - went from ER to delvering babies. She took a chance and got on a flight to NYC one day in the mid 80's and stayed. Here is where she met my dad, had me, and continued working. 

Now, as she was nearing retirement, we were all hoping she would get the rest she finally needed and live life. Of course no one can forsee the future and unfortunately this happened, but I would really love to give something to her that she highly deserves after a long life of working hard and making sacrifices for me so that I could succeed and have a good life.

story:
Low Cost Bio-stimulation Laser (LLLT) with PROGRAMMABLE ROTATING LASERS - .Now with Fractal Pulsewave Architecture

More proof LLLT WORKS - http://health.yahoo.net/articles/laser-liposuction-technique-melts-fat-and-tightens-skin

Special $500 perk with the Cygnus II Android-powered touch screen system - limited to 20 perks. 

For the $500 perk, you’ll get the new Cygnus II Android-powered system – a $995 retail value!  This has rotating, power controlled lasers driven by the Cygnus II system.   Fully programmable Cygnus II rotates the lasers in 3 axes; controls their power dynamically, adjusts for certain body targets, and literally helps you get the body you want faster than ever.  It does things LLLT machines coating tens of thousands can’t do.  Rotating lasers cover an entire area with one sitting.  Only systems costing thousands more have rotating laser heads.  The adjustable stand makes positioning the lasers easy and quick.

 

The most advanced Low Level Laser Therapy system on the planet can be yours for half the retail price of $995 if you act quickly.  The Cygnus II is a unique Android-powered system that it has a 7" touch screen LCD display, an adjustable stand that holds twelve 100 mw lasers so you do not have to hold them, and is run with a 32 bit microprocessor. It is fully Internet connected, runs Android apps, and will even play your music and videos. The system will run the whole world of Android apps and a host of other functions while precisely controlling the lasers to make your body even better. We’re adding even more functions all the time.

People want to lose weight, improve their looks, and just feel better.  Here’s your chance for half price.  Act now before the twenty $500 perks are all gone. 

 

People want to lose weight, improve their looks, and just feel better.  Here’s your chance for half price.  Act now before they are all gone. 

New Addition - Flexible LLLT Belt - Special Perk Added

The rage in personal enhancement is LLLT

   Bio-Stimulation or Low Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) is sweeping the world because it does so much to improve people’s lives.  The problem, though, is cost.  A trip to a laser clinic can cost $1,295 to $20,000.  When you breakdown what they are doing at the clinic, you realize all they are doing is shining a laser diode on your body.  These diodes are rated at 100 milliwatts or less.  The equipment, however, can cost over $25,000.    Instead of paying for these incredibly expensive prices and using incredibly expensive machines, we can do exactly the same thing for a mere fraction of the cost.  Innumerable studies from reputable sources have shown all the bells and whistles they put on these high cost machines are not really needed.  Just put the lasers on your body for certain length of time and get exactly the same results.    We have developed, tested, and are ready to produce a low cost unit that will do what the expensive units will do for pennies on the dollar.  Our unit has two 100 mw 650 nm laser diodes with an expected lifespan of 10,000 hours.  It even has a feature not found in the expensive units – a safety switch.  To make sure the lasers never go on without being against the body, a tiny plunger activates the lasers.    But, you need to know what these lasers have been reported by others as doing.  While we make no claims and/or guarantees, here’s a partial list with a URL to examine:   

  • Weight Loss/Liposuction - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20393809
  • Smoking Cessation - http://coldlasersupplies.com/cold-laser-quit-smoking-q-and-a
  • Body Sculpting - http://www.modernmedicine.com/modern-medicine/news/modernmedicine/modern-medicine-news/low-level-laser-therapy-body-sculpting-asse
  • Hair Loss - http://hairfoundation.org/hair-library/article-llt.htm
  • Erectile Dysfunction – http://www.laser.nu/lllt/lllt_editorial11.htm 
  • Neck Pain - http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/170796.php
  • Wound Healing - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC522143/
  • Low Back Pain - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18425909
  • Knee Pain - http://www.dnpglobalinc.com/pain.htm
  • Nerve Regeneration - http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17508846
  • High Blood Pressure - http://www.mediclights.com/effect-of-low-level-laser-therapy-on-hypertension/
  • Diabetes - http://www.drkaslow.com/html/low_level_lasers__lllt_.html
  • Sleep Disorder - http://www.mediclights.com/treat-insomnia-sleep-disorder-naturally/
    • Personal experience - I used to be able to sleep just a few hours a night.  After using the lasers just once, I go to sleep almost immediately and sleep up to 10 hours - every night.
  • General Benefits Explained - http://wolfweb.unr.edu/homepage/bruch/presentation/lllt.pdf
  • Veterinary Uses - http://www.danscottandassociates.com/files/Product%20Photos/PWC/12-2%20Q%201000%20Low%20Level%20Studies.pdf
  1. Non-Toxic       
  2. Non-Invasive
  3. Easy to  Apply
  4. No Side Effects or Pain
  5. Extremely Safe
  6. Cost Effective
  7. Highly Effective for Patient (>90% efficacy)
  8. Growing Acceptance of Laser Technology
  9. Superior Alternative to: Analgesics & Other Medications, Other Modalities
  10. Reduces Need for Surgery
  11. Virtually No Contra-Indications

 So many more.  Look up your interest on Google with the ‘LLLT’ keyword.  You’ll almost certainly find where LLLT has come to the rescue.       In the final analysis, all anyone is doing is shining laser diodes on a person’s body.  We can do that inexpensively.  We bought some high quality 100 mw 650 nm (red light) diodes, printed a case on our 3D printer, and hooked up a 5 volt power source.  Presto!  We had what these expensive clinics had.  We put the output against our stomach and the inches vanished.  We knew we had a good product.    What we have left to do is get the molds made so we can manufacture these.  Before we do that, we have to get FDA, UL, and CE approval.  As it is only 100 mw, FDA approval should be a snap.  The UL and CE approval will not be a problem because we will be using a wall adapter that already has UL, CE, and CEC approval.  Thus, we are ready to give the world a low cost alternative to expensive LLLT clinics.

If we don't raise enough money, anyone who does contribute at least $100 will be given lasers printed from our 3D printer.

story:
Short Summary

Breast cancer is an insidious disease and it's treatments can be enormously cruel and unpredictable.  Years have passed by as we look for the cure but still, we find ourselves picking up the pieces.

That is the main purpose of project AWOL (A Way Of Life...after breast cancer) is intended to do just that.  By offering retreats for breast cancer survivors, we can provide a sense of normalcy again after life gave you a time that wasn't so normal. 

Breast cancder is a life changing experience and can bring anxiety, depression, feelings of loss or disconnect, feelings of not being so pretty or feminine.  The disease and the treatment can make a person feel she is so imposing on the ones they love, they don't ask for help as much as they should.  Particularly after reatment has been completed.

Issues of body image can also be minimized by self, clinicians, family, and even people in the support system due to the potentially life threatening component of cancer.

In a safe and comfortable environment, our retreats offer

- Trust Building: Customized exercises which allow for letting go vs. controlling.  Instinctually women are nurturers, often making it difficult to receive their much needed care from others.  These reflective group exercises help guests understand that it’s OK to receive.

 - Art Fun: Specially tailored workshops are offered as a healing art.  Providing a safe and supporting environment along with these expressive arts facilitates introspection and growth our guests hold on to long after the weekend has ended.

- Massage: Touching helps the body’s level of stress hormones decrease and the level of endorphins increase; touch is important for survival itself.  Because a woman
who may have had a mastectomy could feel self-conscious, she may be less likely
to seek out a massage, making this element of our retreat especially important. 
Our nurturing therapists provide  a safe environment where our guests can
indulge. 

- Yoga: Our certified instructors lead classes that not only provide exercise, but also affect a person's emotional well-being; including dynamic interplay of movements, breathing exercises, meditations, lifestyle skills, rituals, gestures, and healing sounds.

- Photo Shoot:  we have an array of photographers, make-up artists, and hair designers helping to bring out the natural beauty that each woman holds within her, capturing it forever in our individualized and personalized photography. 

- Wonderful Loving Surprises:  Throughout the entire retreat.

No one receives pay for their services through project AWOL.  Everyone on this project is a volunteer.  Everyone! 

 What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $10,000 to cover the cost of retreat center and food.
  • This will cover a total of 30 scholarships given to individuals who suffer financial hardship.
  • It is not unusual that 90% of our recipients per retreat need a scholarship due to financial hardship. 
  • Should we not reach our goal, all funding will be directly placed in our scholarship fund.

The Impact

It is difficult to know when the madness will stop because, as of today, we still have not found a cure.  The pieces are falling ad we are here to pick them up through this great project.

Your contribution can make such a difference.  It will help us provide the help much needed to bring many women back on their journey to well being and to a higher sense of self.

In Southern California alone, we have helped over 500 breast cancer survivors since 2003 and many others from all over the country.

Our volunteers continue to give as they return retreat after retreat, wanting to help even more each time.  Most are breast cancer survivors who have attended our retreat and came back so they could give back.  We even have a waiting list of volunteers.

We hope you can also help us continue our good work by funding project AWOL.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us make some noise about project AWOL and please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools.

Thank you for your kind generosity.

story:
Our Story
The Mr. and I met and started dating in 1999, got engaged in 2000 and married in 2001. From the very beginning we talked of having a family, when we were young and naive we talked of 3 children and even started debating names. Here we are on the cusp of celebrating 11 years of marriage and we have yet to achieve a viable pregnancy.

In June of 2005 we officially began trying to conceive. We were hopeful and excitedly anticipated being able to announce that we were pregnant. Month after month we were disappointed that nothing was happening. I convinced myself that it had only been 6 months. We just needed to be patient, to relax, give it time. Then at the 18 month mark I went in for a routine exam and mentioned to the lady doctor that I was concerned as to how long it was taking for me to get pregnant. She asked a few questions, then handed me a card for the infertility clinic and said to give them a call to set up an appointment. I remember sitting in the exam room and feeling like the floor had dropped out from beneath me.

February 2009 we were officially diagnosed as infertile. Hearing those words was beyond difficult and for a period of time we were in shock. It felt like we were just going through the motions of everyday life, trying to wake up from this nightmare.

Once we got our heads wrapped around the idea that we were going to begin infertility treatments. We were put through a battery of tests. They took so many vials of blood I wasn't sure there was any left in my body. I actually prayed that the doctor would find something wrong. If something was wrong then we could work on fixing it. So while it was wonderful news that they found NO reason that we were having such difficulty conceiving, it was also difficult to be given the label of ‘unexplained infertility’.

Once all of the tests were done and we met with the doctor to discuss the results he came up with a plan of action for us. I was once again filled with hope and excitement. Surely this was the answer, we were on our way to building our family.

For three cycles I took 100mg of Clomid for 5 days, had monitoring appointments every few days and intrauterine inseminations. At the end of every cycle was an immeasurable amount of heartache. The nurses and doctor who treated me seemed genuinely confused as to why it wasn’t  working for us. It was time to step up the level of medications. I completed three more cycles this time with Clomid, Menopur and intrauterine inseminations. At the end of it all we were left with empty arms. Kaiser only lets you complete 6 cycles, then they say it is time to move on to more extensive treatments.

The Impact
A few months after we began infertility treatments we decided to make the blog I had been writing open for public viewing, we needed to stop being asked ‘why dont you have kids yet?’, we wanted support from our friends and family while navigating this journey. The love that flowed from others reading our blog and responding to us was incredible. I have had complete strangers thank us for sharing our story, tell us they were praying for us and give us a pat on the back for being brave enough to speak out. If you want a more detailed account of where we have been and continued updates as we move forward through IVF you can check out the blog at www.cautionarywhale.blogspot.com. 

It is difficult to put into words how much it means to us that we have so many cheering us on. At times I am moved to tears because of the level of kindness and generosity from our friends. Thank you may never seem like enough, but know that from the depths of my soul I am grateful beyond comprehension for each and every one of you because you have had a huge impact on our lives.

What We Need
This brings us to the present. We are pursuing IVF as our next step in treatment.  For the past year and a half we have been making sacrifices to save money as well as collecting recyclables and having garage sales with the incredible help of so many of our dear friends and family in order to build up our IVF account. It has been a long and exhausting journey and we are still short of our goal. We are now asking for your help in our final push so that we can make our dream become reality. While there are no guarantees that IVF will work for us, there is no reason to think it wont. We have brought our hopes and fears to the Lord. Every step so far we have felt His presence and that He is guiding us through this journey.

Our health insurances do not cover any of the costs we will incur from IVF.
ALL donations will ONLY be used for infertility related costs!

An IVF cycle 
Monitoring appointments                  Ultrasounds
Lab Work                                       Infertility Medications
Anestesia                                       Egg retrieval
Fertilization                                    Assisted Embryo Hatching
Embryo Transfer                              Pregnancy testing

Putting a price on having children is impossible. Helping our wish come true is priceless. We will be forever grateful for any amount you are able to give... every dollar counts. If you are unable to contribute financially to our IVF fund we understand, prayers mean just as much to us.

Please pray for guidance as we prepare to embark on the next leg of our journey, pray for comfort, peace and that we conceive during this process. We believe in the power of prayer, and its ability to do great things.

Please SPREAD THE WORD by adding a link from this page to your facebook, twitter or blog. The more people who see this the better chance we have of reaching our goal.
story_txt:
Our StoryThe Mr. and I met and started dating in 1999, got engaged in 2000 and married in 2001. From the very beginning we talked of having a family, when we were young and naive we talked of 3 children and even started debating names. Here we are on the cusp of celebrating 11 years of marriage and we have yet to achieve a viable pregnancy. In June of 2005 we officially began trying to conceive. We were hopeful and excitedly anticipated being able to announce that we were pregnant. Month after month we were disappointed that nothing was happening. I convinced myself that it had only been 6 months. We just needed to be patient, to relax, give it time. Then at the 18 month mark I went in for a routine exam and mentioned to the lady doctor that I was concerned as to how long it was taking for me to get pregnant. She asked a few questions, then handed me a card for the infertility clinic and said to give them a call to set up an appointment. I remember sitting in the exam room and feeling like the floor had dropped out from beneath me.February 2009 we were officially diagnosed as infertile. Hearing those words was beyond difficult and for a period of time we were in shock. It felt like we were just going through the motions of everyday life, trying to wake up from this nightmare. Once we got our heads wrapped around the idea that we were going to begin infertility treatments. We were put through a battery of tests. They took so many vials of blood I wasn't sure there was any left in my body. I actually prayed that the doctor would find something wrong. If something was wrong then we could work on fixing it. So while it was wonderful news that they found NO reason that we were having such difficulty conceiving, it was also difficult to be given the label of ‘unexplained infertility’. Once all of the tests were done and we met with the doctor to discuss the results he came up with a plan of action for us. I was once again filled with hope and excitement. Surely this was the answer, we were on our way to building our family. For three cycles I took 100mg of Clomid for 5 days, had monitoring appointments every few days and intrauterine inseminations. At the end of every cycle was an immeasurable amount of heartache. The nurses and doctor who treated me seemed genuinely confused as to why it wasn’t  working for us. It was time to step up the level of medications. I completed three more cycles this time with Clomid, Menopur and intrauterine inseminations. At the end of it all we were left with empty arms. Kaiser only lets you complete 6 cycles, then they say it is time to move on to more extensive treatments.The ImpactA few months after we began infertility treatments we decided to make the blog I had been writing open for public viewing, we needed to stop being asked ‘why dont you have kids yet?’, we wanted support from our friends and family while navigating this journey. The love that flowed from others reading our blog and responding to us was incredible. I have had complete strangers thank us for sharing our story, tell us they were praying for us and give us a pat on the back for being brave enough to speak out. If you want a more detailed account of where we have been and continued updates as we move forward through IVF you can check out the blog at www.cautionarywhale.blogspot.com. 
It is difficult to put into words how much it means to us that we have so many cheering us on. At times I am moved to tears because of the level of kindness and generosity from our friends. Thank you may never seem like enough, but know that from the depths of my soul I am grateful beyond comprehension for each and every one of you because you have had a huge impact on our lives.What We NeedThis brings us to the present. We are pursuing IVF as our next step in treatment.  For the past year and a half we have been making sacrifices to save money as well as collecting recyclables and having garage sales with the incredible help of so many of our dear friends and family in order to build up our IVF account. It has been a long and exhausting journey and we are still short of our goal. We are now asking for your help in our final push so that we can make our dream become reality. While there are no guarantees that IVF will work for us, there is no reason to think it wont. We have brought our hopes and fears to the Lord. Every step so far we have felt His presence and that He is guiding us through this journey. Our health insurances do not cover any of the costs we will incur from IVF.ALL donations will ONLY be used for infertility related costs!An IVF cycle Monitoring appointments                  UltrasoundsLab Work                                       Infertility MedicationsAnestesia                                       Egg retrievalFertilization                                    Assisted Embryo HatchingEmbryo Transfer                              Pregnancy testingPutting a price on having children is impossible. If you are unable to contribute financially to our IVF fund we understand, prayers mean just as much to us.
Please pray for guidance as we prepare to embark on the next leg of our journey, pray for comfort, peace and that we conceive during this process. story:
What is the Health Foundation about?

The Jacqueline Sidman Health Foundation is a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization that was founded by Dr. Jacqueline Sidman in 2007. The purpose is to research how, by working directly with the subconscious mind positive, often immediate, effects can be achieved for one's physical and mental health. Various approaches will be evaluated through clinical studies and trials to be disseminated to the scientific and general public showing the results of the studies.
The first study focuses on healing depression and anxiety in women.
Results from the first study will show how depression and anxiety can be eliminated in a very short time without the use of medication. Our goal is to discover the optimal method for achieving greatly improved mental and physical health through the use of Short-Term Sidman Hypnotherapy (STSH).

Dr. Sidman formed the foundation because there was lack of concrete evidence to prove to the medical community and the public how effectively the subconscious mind can work to help individuals achieve a greater quality of life. If emotional stress can be diminished in this way, the foundation believes that years of suffering can literally be prevented.

 

 

Dr. Sidman was invited to be a featured speaker for the faculty at UCI Medical Center and, as a result, she attracted scientists that helped her create the Foundation and serve to this day on the Board of Directors. It is the Foundation’s hope that the research will show proof that the amazing outcomes are real and can become a new tool for other therapists to utilize so that these fast and effective non-invasive results that can become available to everyone. Her passion is that her mission will be fulfilled in her lifetime, as time is of the essence, and this system will create a happier and more successful world for all people in future generations, so that they don’t have to suffer like previous generations. 

 

How will the community benefit when case study results are published?

Depression is a serious condition that can impact many areas of someone’s life. It affects social life, relationships, career, and sense of self-worth. For women in particular, depression is common. According to the National Mental Health Association, about one in every eight women will develop depression at some point during her lifetime.

Through research conducted by this Foundation, our hope is to provide a viable choice for larger numbers of women to have an opportunity to reduce their depression and anxiety in a very short time without the use of drugs or long-term therapy.

Dr. Sidman was encouraged to form this foundation so that her life's work of accessing the subconscious mind directly can be a positive contribution in order to create a "gold standard" in the field of psychological treatment, therefore becoming a worthwhile alternative for the medical community to naturally restore the health of millions of people.

Why depression?

Depression limits people from leading a fulfilling life. It can lead to many health issues, including weight issues, alcohol addiction, insomnia, heart disease, and other medical illness. In the United States, about 15 million people experience depression each year and the majority of them are women. Nearly two-thirds do not get the help they need, and depression carries a high risk of suicide.

Is there any proof yet?

Results have already been published in The Journal of Reproductive Medicine in 2009 for this short-term drug-free technique (STSH or Short-Term Sidman Hypnotherapy) healing an intractable disease called Interstitial Cystitis that was anxiety based. This is the premier OB/GYN journal in the world, and there has never been a cure for this disease until this method, so this case was notable enough for publication in this highly respected journal. The far-reaching application of this work can help relieve anxiety and stress-related illnesses, as well.

Our first study protocol has already been approved by the IRB, (the Institutional Review Board), showing no harm will come to human subjects. This first controlled study will compare STSH technique with medications that have side-effects and “black-box” warnings. This technique is natural with no side-effects and has shown long-lasting results. The Foundation plans to employ a significant number of employees to conduct this study.

In a preliminary pilot study using STSH, with a small group of individuals, conducted by the Foundation, results were proven through testing that all individuals in the study reduced their depression and anxiety from high to minimal levels without the use of medication within six sessions.

In the proposed study, a large number of people in three separate groups will be compared thereby showing control groups to prove the hypothesis. One group will be only on medication; the second group will be on medication and also be treated with STSH, and the third group will only experience the STSH treatment.

Why contribute? What are you being helpful for?

As a result of the preliminary study, it has been proven that STSH is incredibly effective, fast and safe. However, due to financial constraints, we are not able to get the study published or conduct the larger control-group study, and need your help in order to be funded so that we can make this treatment available to large numbers of people.

How will you contribute?

The disbursement of your contributions will be allocated for:

  • advertisements for personnel, including their training
  • office space
  • furniture
  • equipment and supplies
  • subjects to participate in the study
  • interviews and testing,
  • transportation
  • insurances
  • primary investigators and other staff

 

Our goal is to raise a total of $300,000 in order to conduct the proposed research study that will take 2 years to complete.

What will you get?

Each contribution will receive a letter of appreciation from The Jacqueline Sidman Foundation.

Particular bigger amounts ($100 and above) will be listed on different special levels of recognition divided to ranges on our Health Foundation website (Bronze, Silver, Gold, Premium, Platinum and Diamond level contributor)

 

 

Please take a look at our website: http://www.jacquelinesidmanhealthfoundation.org/

story:
[The Idea.]

We are Aaron and Missy, a nurse and medical student dedicated to health equity. We will be sleeping outside throughout the freezing Duluth, MN winter to raise funds for Socmed (http://www.socmedglobal.org/index.html), a 501(c)3 nonprofit that focuses on the ways in which social determinants (e.g. not being able to sleep in a warm bed) can impact the health and wellbeing of individuals and society. 

Make your impact a postive one.

Understanding the social determinants of health is so incredibly important to us because it inspires more inclusive perspectives and frames equity in a direct relationship to health outcomes. We want to provide our future patients the most understanding, holistic care possible-realizing that their entire life experience contributes to the basis of their disease.

We support SocMed to inspire future health care providers to look beyond the biologic basis of disease, and to truly look at a patient for who they are, and not only the disease they may have. 

 

Praxis- Putting ideas into action.

SocMed runs an immersion course in Uganda that incorporates innovative teaching methodologies to merge teaching of clinical tropical medicine with understanding of the socioeconomic, cultural, political, and historical underpinnings of illness. Enrollment is open to health professional students in their clinical years from across the globe, and includes equal participation of Ugandan students.

Personal- Where and what we come from matters.

Who we are and where we come from matters deeply in healthcare delivery. Critical self-awareness enhances our ability to undo harmful structural and societal factors of which we are all part.

Partnership- Advancing equity, together.

SocMed utilizes a curriculum that places great importance on building personal partnerships and encouraging students to reflect upon their personal experiences with power, privilege, race, class, gender, and sexual orientation as central to effective partnership building in global health.

 

[The Impact.] 

SocMed is a young organization, and donating a little will go a long way.

Whether or not we reach our goal, here is where the money goes:

  • Running the annual course in Northern Uganda for thirty future leaders in health care from Uganda and around the World.

 

  • Expanding to a second site in Haiti in collaboration with Physicians for Haiti (http://physiciansforhaiti.org/)

 

  • Establishing a scholarship fund for students from resource-poor settings who otherwise could not attend the course

 

  • Beginning construction on the planned Center for the Study of Social Medicine in Northern Uganda to create a permanent, concentrated space for study, research, and advocacy related to social medicine

 

  • Financially supporting the Oryema Fellowship in Social Medicine, a part-time position to maximize the potential of SocMed

  

[What YOU Get.]

As a thank you for your generosity, you will receive one of the following: 

1. A Warm Fuzzy

2. Homemade Meal and Conversation

3. Handmade Glass Jewelry 

4. Handmade Leather Coin Purse or Wallet

5. Custom Designed Leather Purse or Backpack

 

[More Ways to Help.]

Share this indiegogo link and spread the word. 

  • indiegogo.com/sleepoutforsocmed 

Visit this website to learn about SocMed.

  • http://www.socmedglobal.org 

"Like" us on Facebook

  • https://www.facebook.com/groups/320611631381513/

Consider spending a night in the cold and tell us your thoughts and reflections!

story:
A week before Thanksgiving, my mom was diagnosed with multiple myeloma, a cancer starts in the plasma cells in bone marrow. She will lose her hair in 2013 while she undergoes a stem cell transplant. 

My sister, our friend Erin, my daughter and I donated our hair so she can have a wig. My mom is the most giving and selfless person I know. Please help us make this possible for her!

If we exceed our goal, the rest of money will go towards mom's medical bills. Even with insurance, the cost of her chemotherapy is outrageously expensive. 

We've felt so loved throughout this journey. Thank you so much for your support!

Check out her CaringBridge for the most up-to-date information: 

http://www.caringbridge.org/visit/teresacarpenter

story:
My Story: 7 Scoliosis Surgeries 

    I was officially diagnosed with serve Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (S curve) and Kyphosis at age 11. When I first heard that I might even have Scoliosis I was so scared. Scoliosis is an abnormal curving of the spine. Your spine is your backbone. It runs straight down your back. Everyone’s spine naturally curves a tiny bit. But people with scoliosis have a spine that curves too much. The spine might look like the letter “C” or “S.” Kyphosis is a curving of the spine that causes a bowing or rounding of the back, which leads to a hunchback or slouching posture.



We went to my doctors and they did the standard Scoliosis Screening Test then I started treatment in San Diego, California at USNMC Balboa. I wore a TLSO Brace or Boston Brace for 23 hours a day. I could only take it off for middle school gym class. I felt I could hide my biggest flaw 95% of the time but there is no hiding the giant plastic corset when your changing into sweats. To add to my distress of all the changes to my body, I had to bring my bace to the office because it did not fit into my locker.

 

After wearing the brace religiously for a year my curve was still progressing. I was very scared when they sent me to have a MRI and a CT Scan. There was no way around it I needed surgery, my spine was so twisted and bent it was crushing my lungs, making it hard to breathe and inching closer to twisting around my heart.
My first fusion surgery, with Harrington rods occurred in December 2000. I was in the hospital’s ICU for 2 days and then moved to the regular ward for 4 days. The surgery was deemed as a success. 
My spine was good for the first few years then I had increased pain which led me back to the doctors where it was discovered that I had pseudarthosis in my spine and my spine was not fully fused. 

In 2005 I had my second surgery where my rods were removed, but they did not replace my rods right away hoping that the half of my spine that was fused would hold the curve and I would not need a third surgery. However, six months later my curves were getting worse and we planned my third surgery. I was placed in traction and a halo for a week to “stretch me” they replaced my rods and added screws while also preforming a spine lateral release.  During my many different forms of treatment for My Scoliosis I also had other complications inducing:

  • Acquired Hip Dysplasia
  • Chronic Kidney Stones
  • Chronic Osteomyelitis
  • Collapsed Lungs
  • Dermatitis
  • Depression
  • Femorocetabluar Impingement (FAI)
  • Stomach ulcers
  • Upper Respiratory Infections

    In 2008 my spine was “falling forward” and I had increased pain therefore my rods were removed and it was discovered that infection of Osteomyelitis was present. I was given a PIC line for another year, and braced with a TSLO Brace. In 2009 I had my last surgeries at USCD by Thornton. He did the first surgery to make sure no infection was present even though my tests were clear. Then the next surgery was to replace my rods. I am now fully fused from T3-L3 and nearly two years post opt. 

    Throughout my twisted journey I battled not only medical difficulties, but myself. There was a time in my life when I was not the positive, upbeat Scoliosis Girl I am today. I was bullied, made fun of and shun for my disorder, a disorder I did not choose. I felt alone and hopeless but through time and healing I have found that I’m so much more then a curved spine.

     Since being diagnosed with Scoliosis I educated myself as much as possible and quickly learned that scoliosis was a disease that tends to be diagnosed in pre-teen years in 1 in 40 kids. It is treated with a range of strategies that includes braces, physical therapies, and invasive spine surgeries. Along the way, kids with scoliosis frequently face challenges such as:

  • Physical discomfort and pain resulting from scoliosis and/or bracing
  • Self-consciousness around body image and braces
  • Avoidance of embarrassing situations where the secret of the brace or body deformity might be exposed
  • Fears of facing major reconstructive surgery


Since learning and dealing with my own feelings of loneliness and a struggle for acceptance this I founded my own Scoliosis Awareness site My Scoliosis Story and became the Chapter Director of the Curvy Girls of Southern Califorina.  Scoliosis is my passion because I believe it’s my personal mission  to spread awareness about Scoliosis and provided a message of empowerment to all those effected by this disorder.

To see me and action click the links!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/myscoliosisstory
Twitter: https://twitter.com/ScoliosisStory
YouTube:http://www.youtube.com/myscoliosisstory


     


The Impact of your donation: 
The Curvy Girl groups are peer lead support groups empowering pre- teen and teen girls to become leaders, make healthy lifestyle choices, and improve self-esteem by diminishing the emotional impact of scoliosis.We seek to help girls find their voice through support and acceptance. These donations allow me to attend the 1st Curvy Girl Convention to learn more and approve my motivational skills to better help those in the Scoliosis Community. 

·   Effective Advocacy Strategies for Kids and Adults

·   Nutrition For a Healthy Spine

·   Finding Your Voice vs. Fears

·   Emerging Science, Rehabilitation & Treatment

·   Scoliosis Fashion Show

·   Motivational Speakers

·   Conservative Treatment

 

What I Will Use the Donations For:
 I estimate that I'll need $2,000 to continue my passion of Scoliosis Awareness!  That will include airfare, accommodations, travel, meals, and the conference.

Airline Ticket San Diego - New York          : $744
Hotel Reservations in New York 4 nights   : $756

Transportation to/from airport and hotel    : $200
Conference Ticket + Meals                          :$300

                                                        Total: $2,000 
If we reach our goal, everything listed above will be able to happen, I will go to the first ever Curvy Girl Scoliosis Girl Conference continue on with my mission to spread Scoliosis Awareness and You get your awesome perks!

If I exceed my person goal, all of the proceeds will be sent to the National Curvy Girl Charter and help other girls who need some extra funding to be able to attend the National Conference.

Need more details? Here is the Break Down:

Airline Ticket
from San Diego Airport to Islip Long Island (roundtrip)   
Flight Prices go up the longer I wait to get my tickets. I will get the cheapest airfare possible. (US Airways Flights 2 stops from $690- $740 + taxes and baggage fees)
$730- $780 

Hotel Reservations
Conference will be held at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Hauppauge, NY, rooms are subject to space availability and current hotel rates of $189.00 per night. I need to be at where the conference is being held in order not to rent a car or try an navigate around New York.
$756
Conference
Attending Curvy Girl Scoliosis Support Conference (3 Days) Objectives are Scoliosis Management, Education and Empowerment. Conference ticket goes directly to the Hotel to pay for the room for the Conference.  Ticket includes 6 meals, 4 break snacks, and workshops for each person registered.
$300

Transportation to get to/from the my town of Temecula (67.4 miles each way /134.8 miles total) to San Diego Airport $57 gas + Parking ($21 for first day, $26  Additional Days day, $99 total in parking fees) 

$156
Taxi-Long Island Airport to Hotel to Hauppauge, NY (8.3 miles each way/16.6 miles)
$2.50 to jump in a taxi, $1.25 a mile x 8.3 miles - $10.37 (with no taffic) $12.87 each way ($25.74 + Tip)

$35.74 

Grand Total: $1977.74 - $2117.74

 

Strapped for Cash? You Can Still Help Give BACK!

  • Share this event and support Scoliosis Awareness, above is link to repost to Facebook, send it to Twitter or email.
  • Become a fan of My Scoliosis Story, at http://www.facebook.com/myscoliosisstory !
  • Also If you know a pre-teen or teen with scoliosis, I would be happy to talk to them about the Curvy Girls support group.  There are chapters all over the country and internationally. New members are always welcome and it has been a great, fun support for me through my scoliosis journey.

story_txt:
My Story: 7 Scoliosis Surgeries 
    I was officially diagnosed with serve Adolescent Idiopathic Scoliosis (S curve) and Kyphosis at age 11. When I first heard that I might even have Scoliosis I was so scared. Scoliosis is an abnormal curving of the spine. Your spine is your backbone. It runs straight down your back. Everyone’s spine naturally curves a tiny bit. But people with scoliosis have a spine that curves too much. The spine might look like the letter “C” or “S.” Kyphosis is a curving of the spine that causes a bowing or rounding of the back, which leads to a hunchback or slouching posture.

We went to my doctors and they did the standard Scoliosis Screening Test then I started treatment in San Diego, California at USNMC Balboa. I wore a TLSO Brace or Boston Brace for 23 hours a day. I could only take it off for middle school gym class. I felt I could hide my biggest flaw 95% of the time but there is no hiding the giant plastic corset when your changing into sweats. To add to my distress of all the changes to my body, I had to bring my bace to the office because it did not fit into my locker.

 
 After wearing the brace religiously for a year my curve was still progressing. I was very scared when they sent me to have a MRI and a CT Scan. There was no way around it I needed surgery, my spine was so twisted and bent it was crushing my lungs, making it hard to breathe and inching closer to twisting around my heart. My first fusion surgery, with Harrington rods occurred in December 2000. I was in the hospital’s ICU for 2 days and then moved to the regular ward for 4 days. The surgery was deemed as a success.  My spine was good for the first few years then I had increased pain which led me back to the doctors where it was discovered that I had pseudarthosis in my spine and my spine was not fully fused. 
In 2005 I had my second surgery where my rods were removed, but they did not replace my rods right away hoping that the half of my spine that was fused would hold the curve and I would not need a third surgery. However, six months later my curves were getting worse and we planned my third surgery. I was placed in traction and a halo for a week to “stretch me” they replaced my rods and added screws while also preforming a spine lateral release.  During my many different forms of treatment for My Scoliosis I also had other complications inducing:

Acquired Hip Dysplasia
Chronic Kidney Stones
Chronic Osteomyelitis
Collapsed Lungs
Dermatitis
Depression
Femorocetabluar Impingement (FAI)
Stomach ulcers
Upper Respiratory Infections

    In 2008 my spine was “falling forward” and I had increased pain therefore my rods were removed and it was discovered that infection of Osteomyelitis was present. I was given a PIC line for another year, and braced with a TSLO Brace. In 2009 I had my last surgeries at USCD by Thornton. He did the first surgery to make sure no infection was present even though my tests were clear. Then the next surgery was to replace my rods. I am now fully fused from T3-L3 and nearly two years post opt. 
    Throughout my twisted journey I battled not only medical difficulties, but myself. There was a time in my life when I was not the positive, upbeat Scoliosis Girl I am today. I was bullied, made fun of and shun for my disorder, a disorder I did not choose. I felt alone and hopeless but through time and healing I have found that I’m so much more then a curved spine.
     Since being diagnosed with Scoliosis I educated myself as much as possible and quickly learned that scoliosis was a disease that tends to be diagnosed in pre-teen years in 1 in 40 kids. It is treated with a range of strategies that includes braces, physical therapies, and invasive spine surgeries. Along the way, kids with scoliosis frequently face challenges such as:

Physical discomfort and pain resulting from scoliosis and/or bracing
Self-consciousness around body image and braces
Avoidance of embarrassing situations where the secret of the brace or body deformity might be exposed
Fears of facing major reconstructive surgery

 Since learning and dealing with my own feelings of loneliness and a struggle for acceptance this I founded my own Scoliosis Awareness site My Scoliosis Story and became the Chapter Director of the Curvy Girls of Southern Califorina.  Scoliosis is my passion because I believe it’s my personal mission  to spread awareness about Scoliosis and provided a message of empowerment to all those effected by this disorder.
To see me and action click the links!
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/myscoliosisstory Twitter: https://twitter.com/ScoliosisStory YouTube:http://www.youtube.com/myscoliosisstory
     
The Impact of your donation:  The Curvy Girl groups are peer lead support groups empowering pre- teen and teen girls to become leaders, make healthy lifestyle choices, and improve self-esteem by diminishing the emotional impact of scoliosis.We seek to help girls find their voice through support and acceptance. These donations allow me to attend the 1st Curvy Girl Convention to learn more and approve my motivational skills to better help those in the Scoliosis Community. 
·   Effective Advocacy Strategies for Kids and Adults
·   Nutrition For a Healthy Spine
·   Finding Your Voice vs. Fears
·   Emerging Science, Rehabilitation & Treatment
·   Scoliosis Fashion Show
·   Motivational Speakers
·   Conservative Treatment
 
What I Will Use the Donations For:  I estimate that I'll need $2,000 to continue my passion of Scoliosis Awareness!  That will include airfare, accommodations, travel, meals, and the conference.
Airline Ticket San Diego - New York          : $744 Hotel Reservations in New York 4 nights   : $756
Transportation to/from airport and hotel    : $200 Conference Ticket + Meals                          :$300
                                                        Total: $2,000   If we reach our goal, everything listed above will be able to happen, I will go to the first ever Curvy Girl Scoliosis Girl Conference continue on with my mission to spread Scoliosis Awareness and You get your awesome perks!
If I exceed my person goal, all of the proceeds will be sent to the National Curvy Girl Charter and help other girls who need some extra funding to be able to attend the National Conference.

Hotel Reservations  Conference will be held at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Hauppauge, NY, rooms are subject to space availability and current hotel rates of $189.00 per night. I need to be at where the conference is being held in order not to rent a car or try an navigate around New York.  $756Conference  Attending Curvy Girl Scoliosis Support Conference (3 Days) Objectives are Scoliosis Management, Education and Empowerment. Conference ticket goes directly to the Hotel to pay for the room for the Conference.  Ticket includes 6 meals, 4 break snacks, and workshops for each person registered.  $300
